channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Elon Musk Merges SpaceX With His A.I. Start-Up xAI
item.description: The deal further intermingles Mr. Musk’s companies and creates the most valuable private company on earth.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s rocket facility in Boca Chica, Texas.

item.title: Waymo Raises $16 Billion to Fuel Global Ambitions
item.description: The self-driving car company, an arm of Google’s parent company, is rapidly expanding its service beyond a handful of cities.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waymo, Alphabet’s driverless car outfit, said it was now valued at $126 billion.

item.title: A Social Network for A.I. Bots Only. No Humans Allowed.
item.description: A new website called Moltbook has become the talk of Silicon Valley and a Rorschach test for belief in the state of artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Just two days after the social network Moltbook was launched, more than 10,000 “Moltbots” were chatting with one another on the site.

item.title: Move Fast, but Obey the Rules: China’s Vision for Dominating A.I.
item.description: Beijing wants to lead the world in developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, but it also wants companies to adhere to an increasingly complex set of rules.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:description: Executives at Zhipu AI, one of China’s most promising A.I. start-ups, alongside others, at a launch event at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange last month.

item.title: Energy Bills Have Soared Recently. How Can States Bring Costs Down?
item.description: Energy experts said governors and legislatures had tools to keep electricity prices from rising further, and might even be able to lower them.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electricity rates have soared recently in most states.

item.title: Jeff Bezos’s Rocket Company Blue Origin Pauses Space Tourism to Focus on the Moon
item.description: The New Shepard rocket from Blue Origin, which brought 92 people on trips to the edge of space, will cease flying for at least two years as the company prioritizes NASA contracts.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Tesla’s Model S, Soon to Be History, Changed the Auto Industry
item.description: The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, said this week that it would stop making the car, an electric pioneer in 2012, as well as the Model X.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Lexus Division of Toyota Motor Corp
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Model S was a breakthrough and ushered in quite a number of technologies people hadn’t seen before,” said Sam Abuelsamid, an executive at Telemetry, a Detroit communications and research firm.

item.title: Tech Grapples With ICE + Casey Tries Clawdbot, a Risky New A.I. Assistant + HatGPT
item.description: In Minneapolis, it has become a battle of phone versus phone.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Vjeran Pavic, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Rowan Niemisto
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press

item.title: The Tech Arsenal That ICE Has Deployed in Minneapolis
item.description: Agents use facial recognition, social media monitoring and other tech tools not only to identify undocumented immigrants but also to track protesters, current and former officials said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Aaron Krolik
item.media:description: A Border Patrol Agent scanning the face of a driver in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Apple Reports Record iPhone Sales Amid Holiday Bump
item.description: New phone designs, coupled with robust holiday spending, continued to lift iPhone sales in the quarter and drove the company to record profits.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Apple has achieved record sales in its most important business, the iPhone, even though it has lagged other tech giants in the A.I. race.

item.title: OpenAI in Talks to Raise as Much as $100 Billion
item.description: OpenAI’s discussions with Microsoft, Nvidia, Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds and others could value it at $750 billion or more.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times

item.title: How the A.I. Boom Could Push Up the Price of Your Next PC
item.description: A.I. companies are buying up memory chips, causing the prices of those components — which are also used in laptops and smartphones — to soar.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Loren Elliott

item.title: Amazon and Google Eat Into Nvidia’s A.I. Chip Supremacy
item.description: The rivals made billions of dollars in the business over the past year, showing other companies that Nvidia isn’t the only game in town.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Google’s chips for artificial intelligence are increasingly being used by companies other than Google.

item.title: Microsoft Continues to Spend Big on A.I. While Profit Jumps 60%
item.description: The company said on Wednesday that revenue in the most recent quarter was $81.3 billion, but its share price dropped more than 7 percent in after-hours trading.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Microsoft continues to spend billions on building out its data center capacity as the demand for A.I. computing power outweighs its available supply.

item.title: Meta Forecasts Spending of at Least $115 Billion This Year
item.description: That would be a major jump from $72 billion last year, as the tech giant aims to compete in the artificial intelligence race.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta’s Eagle Mountain Data Center in Utah. The bulk of Meta’s new A.I. spending will be on infrastructure like data centers.

item.title: Tesla Profit Slumps, but Investors May Not Care
item.description: The automaker also said it would invest $2 billion in xAI, the artificial intelligence company controlled by its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and stop making the two oldest models in its lineup.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Falling car sales have taken a toll on Tesla’s net profit. The company announced Wednesday that it would stop producing its S and X model cars within months.

item.title: With AlphaGenome, Researchers Are Using A.I. to Decode the Human Blueprint
item.description: AlphaGenome is a leap forward in the ability to study the human blueprint. But the fine workings of our DNA are still largely a mystery.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: DNA electrophoresis in a lab. Scientists at Google DeepMind have trained their A.I on a vast wealth of molecular data, enabling it to make predictions about thousands of genes.

item.title: Amazon to Cut 16,000 Jobs in Latest Round of Layoffs
item.description: The e-commerce giant has been cutting costs while pouring resources into building data centers to compete in the race to dominate artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Microsoft Pledged to Save Water. In the A.I. Era, It Expects Water Use to Soar.
item.description: Driven by the artificial intelligence frenzy, Microsoft is internally projecting that water use at its data centers will more than double by 2030 from 2020, including in places that face shortages.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

item.title: Meta Campaigns to Change Opinions on Data Centers
item.description: The tech giant has spent more than $6 million on TV ads in state capitals and Washington, with the message that data centers create jobs.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan

item.title: TikTok Settles Social Media Addiction Lawsuit Ahead of a Landmark Trial
item.description: The settlement means TikTok will avoid a trial where plaintiffs had planned to argue that social media platforms are inherently defective and subject to personal injury liability.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: TikTok’s offices in Culver City, California.

item.title: G.M. Shares Rise as Investors Are Encouraged by 2026 Prospects
item.description: The automaker said that it would buy back stock worth up to $6 billion and that it expected profit to rise this year after it pulled back from electric vehicle production.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A General Motors factory in Spring Hill, Tenn. G.M. said on Tuesday it planned to introduce a more advanced version of its Super Cruise driver assistance system in 2028.
